awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of Sub-Seasonal Variability of Macro-Monsoon Circulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will address several outstanding questions concerning the weather and climate dynamics of the monsoon regions of the world - Asia, Africa and South America.  One is a better understanding of the dynamics of tropical rainfall variability, with the aim of establishing a firm basis for increased prediction. Of particular interest is the variability on bi-weekly (12-16 days) and intraseasonal (30-50 days) time scales. The PI will examine how the bi-weekly variability develops in the upper atmosphere over Northern Asia and influences monsoon rainfall. These basic dynamical studies will be extend to the other monsoon regions of South America, Indonesia/North Australia, West Africa and North America. The funded research project will examine interaction between the large-scale Asian monsoon circulation and El Nino-Southern Oscillation. These two phenomena are clearly related but the manner of their interaction has not been coherently established. The project will use a blend of data analysis, theoretical fluid dynamics and models of the coupled ocean-atmosphere system.

This improved understanding will be applied to improving precipitation forecasts for these regions, which are faced with rapidly increasing population and increasing need for water and attendant stresses on the food supply. The research findings will be disseminated to scientific societies as well as the general public. This funded project will support PI and his research team to work with the World Bank and apply their monsoon research to forecast products that are being used in South Asia to help build more resilient societies and foster sustaionability.  In collaboration with Climate Forecast Applications Network, the PI will apply this research to improved prediction products for South Asia and South America.

por.por_cntn:
The tropical regions of the planet, roughly between 30°N and 30°S, are unique from a number of perspectives. Because of the curvature of the planet, the tropics receive more heat per square meter from the Sun than do the extratropics creating a latitudinal heating gradient. Oceanic and atmospheric motions, that drive our weather and climate.  However, the heating throughout the tropics is not uniform because of the distribution of oceans and continents as well orographic relief. For example, the  Tibetan-Himalaya Plateau (HTP) complex is the largest on the planet with an area of 2.5x106 km2 (106 square miles) or about 5 times the area of France or one-third the size of Australia, the latter being the oldest and flattest of all continents. Both areas are heated by the sun but as the average elevation of the HTP is about 4,500 m (14,000 ft).  The elevated heating of the atmosphere at the surface of the HTP heating of the atmosphere reversing the temperature gradient between the subtropics and the equator producing a stronger and more varied monsoon with extensive rainfall deep into Asia. By contrast the monsoon circulation over Australia and other land areas in the tropics such as South America and West Africa are moderate, are relatively flat  and this lacking the elevated heating forced by the HTP. The monsoon lands host a very large sector of the world population largely based on agrarian economies. 

Summer rainfall is known to vary on short time scales (1-14 days), subseasonally defining active and “break” periods (25-30 days), seasonally  (3-4 months) and decadally. Given that 80% of agriculture is rain-fed, prior knowledge of future monsoon weather and climate is an imperative for sustainability. 

 

Forecasting extremes in monsoon  weather variability, ranging from floods, heat waves,  drought  and extreme precipitation was our initial priority.   Our efforts were concentrated on extreme events: flooding of major rivers, dry periods and heat waves. We adopted the strategy that it was insufficient to be told  an extreme event would or would occur. We decided that user community needed to know the probability of the probability of the commencement, longevity of the event its intensity providing with  information would allow them to make or choose not to make mitigatory adaptations. We utilized the ensemble forecasts from centers Europe and the US to calculate these probabilities. We developed a forecasting system for Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers in Bangladesh (1, 2), the Indus in Pakistan (3) and heat waves in  western India. 

We had noted earlier (6) that weather forecasts to the developing world would be more useful with two major changes: greater forecast horizon and the use of probabilities.  We have more recently concentrated on shorter term monsoon weather events with the idea that the provision of forecast  to the user level would be useful (7) including the necessity of boundary organizations that link the forecaster and the user. 

 

We have also continued with the “thorny” problems of seasonal and subseasonal monsoon prediction (8,9) which requires understanding the joint interaction of the El Niño phenomena with the monsoon. This progress has been helped by the generation of ensemble prediction on seasonal time scales by a number of centers. However, this is an ongoing project.   

 

 

1: Webster, P.J., J. Jian, T. M. Hopson, C. D. Hoyos, P. Agudelo, H-R. Chang, J. A. Curry, R. L. Grossman, T. N. Palmer, A. R. Subbiah 2010: Extended-range probabilistic forecasts of Ganges and Brahmaputra floods in Bangladesh. Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc. 91, 11, 1493-1514

2. Hopson, T. M., P. J. Webster, 2010: A 1-10 day ensemble forecasting scheme for the major river basins of Bangladesh: forecasting severe floods of 2003-2007. J. Hydromet.  

3. Webster P. J., V. E. Toma and H. M. Kim 2011: Were the 2010 Pakistan Floods predictable? Geophys. Res. Lettrs.,38, L04806, doi: 10.1029/2010GL046346

4. Webster P.J. and K. Shrestha, 2013: An Extended-Range Water Management and Flood Prediction System for the Indus River Basin: Application to the 2010-2012 floods. Report to the World Bank, 2013

5. Shrestha K.Y., P.J. Webster, and V.E. Toma, 2014: An Atmospheric-Hydrologic Forecasting Scheme for the Indus River Basin, Journal of Hydrometeorology. Available at: http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/JHM-D-13-051.1

6. Webster P.J.: Improve weather forecasts for the developing world. Nature, 2013; doi: 10.1038/493017a.

7. P. J. Webster, et al.  2022:. Weather Hazard Prediction & Mitigation in the Developing World. Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society. (submitted)  

8. Wang, J. Li, MA Cane, J. Liu, PJ Webster, BS Xiang, H-M, Kim, J Cao, KJ Ha, 2018: Towards predicting changes in the land monsoon rainfall a decade in advance. J. Clim., 31/7, 2699-2714.

9. Wang, B., B. Xiang, J. Li, P.J. Webster, M.N. Rajeevan, J. Liu, and K.-J. Ha, 2015: Rethinking Indian monsoon rainfall prediction in the context of recent global warming. Nat. Commun., 6, 7154, doi:10.1038/ncomms8154. IPRC-1108
